## Slide 1: The Problem & Our Solution

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### 1. The Problem: A "False Null"

Standard DiD models fail. They mix "symptomatic" (affected) articles with "asymptomatic" (unaffected) ones, **biasing the effect to zero.**

![Naive DiD model finds a null effect.](figures/80pct/event_study_robustness_naive.png){width="100%"}

**Result: Naive LATE $\approx$ 0 (p=0.55)**
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### 2. Our Solution: Algorithmic DiD

We "forward-engineer" the *true* treatment date ($G_i$). Our algorithm (Python) finds *when* each article is *actually* affected.

![Algorithm flowchart for onset detection.](figures/algorithm_flowchart.png){width="90%"}

We then run a Staggered DiD (R) using these *real* cohort dates.
:::
:::

## Slide 2: The Result & The Mechanism

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### 3. The Result: Recovering the LATE

Our method isolates the 14.1% of "symptomatic" articles and finds the true, massive effect.

![Event study using algorithmic onset dates.](figures/80pct/event_study_tech_DAILY_PAGEVIEWS.png){width="100%"}

<div style="background: #f8f9fa; border: 2px solid #D6004A; border-radius: 10px; padding: 15px; text-align: center;">
  <strong>Naive Model:</strong> -1.24 (p=0.55)<br>
  <strong style="color: #D6004A;">Our Method: -7.74 (p<0.01)</strong><br>
  <span style="font-size: 1.5em; color: #D6004A; font-weight: bold;">6x Larger Effect</span>
</div>
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### 4. The Mechanism: Format > Topic

*Why* does this happen? The effect is driven by **visual proximity** on the page, not by topic.

![LATE vs. Spatial Proximity.](figures/80pct/meta_plot_format_proximity.png){width="100%"}

Cannibalization is spatial. Users substitute content that is **visually close**, regardless of its topic.
:::
:::
